title: Can someone please tell me the name of this font? / 'Little Songs of the Chief Officer of Hunar Louse': thin ultra-angular caps
author: no name

comments.content: I'm sorry, did you find a name?

Hi No Name,

welcome to Typophile.  
I have deleted your other 5+ posts with the same request. Let’s focus on this one, okay?  
Quantity doesn’t help. ;-)

Do you have more information on this sample? What’s the source? Is is from an old movie? Keep in mind that it might be hand-lettered. You can find similar typefaces when searching for the keywords ‘faux greek’, or ‘runic’. I haven’t seen this one, though.

And: [Please use a descriptive title next time! Thank you.](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202005920/http:/typophile.com/forum/typeid/faq/#Q_2 "Frequently Asked Question – What do I enter in the “Title” line?")  
F

thanks florian!! I just haven't had any activity, glad you saw my 6th post and decided to answer. It is from a film by the Quay Brothers called The Epic of Gilgamesh, or This Unnameable Little Broom (1985) aka Little Songs of the Chief Officer of Hunar Louse. Thanks again, I really appreciate the help!

You’re welcome. Thanks for providing us with the additional information. Knowing the year (1985) rules out a lot of options.  
 [Rest assured we have had a look at your sample. Sometimes (though rarely) we simply don't have a clue. The best way to ‘revive’ your thread is to post a little reminder in your original thread. Please don't create a duplicate thread with the same request.](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202005920/http:/typophile.com/forum/typeid/faq/#Q_9)
hey thanks reccardo, Faux-runic is close but not exactly what I'm looking for. I appreciate the help!
If you don’t need it for setting _a lot_ of text (which wouldn’t be advisable anyway) – it is a style that you could easily replicate yourself in no time.
yeah, I just need to have the font because I'll be using it for multiple headers
If this is from '85 it is pre-digital, and is probably typeset. I've never seen this before. You might want to check P22's website, they have a number of historical fonts.

I think Chris is right, but there are a few similar fonts: I found [Edessa](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202005920/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/edessa/), [Dalek](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202005920/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/k-type/dalek/) and [Xerxes](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202005920/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/xerxes-tr/). You may find others at gaming sites, or freebie sites like Dafont.

The first of these seems closest in overall feel, and relatively simple changes, like using a C to make the E, should get you pretty close.

- Mike Yanega
